subject: multiple constructors and subclasse (was: "RE: [junit]")
msgSnippet: It is not trivial to discover classes in the classpath that are not yet loaded, let alone discovering such classes that implement/extend a specific type. At
messageBody:
It is not trivial to discover classes in the classpath that are not yet
loaded, let alone discovering such classes that implement/extend a specific
type. At least a naming convention is necessary (as demonstrated by swing
test runner) and the classpath (system property "java.class.path").

BTW, is there really a need for testing all JTextField constructors ? Since
it's super class, JTextComponent has just one (without arguments), and the
other arguments can be set with normal setter methods. In general this is
similar for other swing components because they are all javabeans, and
therefore provide a constructor without arguments.
All JTextField constructors are defined in terms of JTextField(Document,
String, int) - passing null or 1 as defaults.
My conclusion would be to do the same in extended textfield and test that
constructor (EnhancedTextField(Document, String, int)) only.
public EnhancedTextField(){
this(null, null, 1);//and NOT super()
}
By doing so, you would have a single point of control, to guard the internal
state after initialization.

(This is one of the reasons I realy dislike multiple constructors with
arguments and prefer factory methods/factories, at least you can
inherit/override them)

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jacaetevha@...]
> Sent: vrijdag 9 augustus 2002 13:23
> To: JUnit Yahoo Group
> Subject: RE: [junit]
>
>
> I don't think that would be wise. That would then couple the
> framework
> to your business object. You would pass your object into the test
> suite, which would somehow need to pass it off to your test
> case. Your
> test case would have to know about at the highest level in order for
> all test cases to be able to use this construct. It isn't a tight
> coupling, but a coupling all the same.
>
> =jason
>
> P.S. I will write the TestSuiteBuilder tonight or this weekend at
> submit it to the files list. I will say that I don't really like the
> approach though, it was just an option. It opens up room for a lot of
> error in what seems to be one of the weakest areas for Java
> programmers
> (at least in the beginning) - the classpath. What if your
> tests aren't
> all so neatly bundled in the same area? Another issue is what if you
> have UnitTests* and QuickFunctionalTests** and FunctionalTests*** all
> in the same heirarchy of tests? You wouldn't want to have the
> TestSuiteBuilder to include all of them. I will think about a way to
> deal with this. If I can come up with a clean way (without changing
> the framework) I will add this in, if not, well...
>
> =jason
>
> time = (setUp time + test time + tearDown time)
>
> * UnitTest - testing at the method level, generally a very quick
> test (time < 2 seconds)
> ** QuickFunctionalTest - testing functionality
> (FunctionalTest time <
> time > UnitTest time)
> *** FunctionalTest - testing functionality (time > 1.5 minutes)
>
> These numbers are based on what I have done in the past on several
> teams. They are not standards by any stretch of the imagination, just
> guidelines I have used. I found that if my overall UnitTest
> suite took
> more than 2 minutes (which I still consider to be long), I
> was prone to
> run it a lot less. I still would require running UnitTests,
> QuickFunctonalTests, and FunctonalTests before checking in the code!
>
> Of course, this may not work with every project, but so far it has for
> me. No biggie though, so don't start throwing flames anyone. :)
>
> On Fri, 9 Aug 2002 09:18:11 +0200, james.dobson@... said:
> > This message only has an HTML part -- this is a text
> generated representation
> >
> >
> > Writing a TestSuiteBuilder that uses reflection might
> be a good idea,
> > but
> > wouldn't it be better if the functionality we need
> was built into
> > JUnit?
> > Could we add the functionality by extending TestSuite and using a
> > constructor like this:
> > OurTestSuite(java.lang.Class theClass, java.lang.Object
> > objectToTest); ?
> > James
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jacaetevha@...]
> > Sent: 09 August 2002 07:50
> > To: JUnit Yahoo Group
> > Subject: Re: [junit]
> > Of course, you could have a utility class, like a
> TestSuiteBuilder,
> > that will scan the classpath via reflection and build up the test
> > suite. The code is simple enough in Java (easier in
> Smalltalk though
> > :) that it shouldn't take more than a few minutes, make
> it 10 if you
> > write it test first. :)
> > =jason
> > On Thu, 08 Aug 2002 01:50:43 -0400, "J. B. Rainsberger"
> > <jbr@...> said:
> > > This message only has an HTML part -- this is a text generated
> > representation
> > >
> > >
> > > I say AbstractTestCase is your best bet.
> It removes the
> > pain of
> > > calling
> > > addTestSuite(Class), from what I can see. You
> could always use
> > Ruby to
> > > generate the test classes...
> > > Good luck.
> > > *********** REPLY SEPARATOR ***********
> > > On 2002-08-07 at 12:27 james.dobson@... wrote:
> > > >Hi Everyone,
> > > >
> > > >Is it possible to automatically add all the
> tests of a test
> > class to
> > > a
> > > >suite
> > > >without using 'suite.addTestSuite(MyTest.class)'?
> > > >
> > > >I have a test class that can test a number of
> classes from the
> > same
> > > >hierarchy. Let's say for arguments
> sake that I have
> > created two
> > > child
> > > >classes (ChildA and ChildB) of type
> JTextComponent and both of
> > them
> > > >override
> > > >a number of methods such as setText. I have a
> number of tests
> > that
> > > test
> > > >the
> > > >newly overridden methods. I have created a
> constructor for the
> > class
> > > that
> > > >looks something like this:
> > > >
> > > > public MyTest(String name, JTextComponent component)
> > > > {
> > > > super(name);
> > > > this.component = component;
> > > > }
> > > >
> > > >My problem is this: I want to run this test
> twice, once for
> > childA
> > > and
> > > once
> > > >for childB. But I don't want to type in the
> tests individually
> > e.g.
> > > >
> > > > public class MyTestClient
> > > > {
> > > > public static Test suite()
> > > > {
> > > > TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> > > >
> > > > suite.addTest(new
> MyTest("test1", new
> > ChildA()));
> > > > suite.addTest(new
> MyTest("test2", new
> > ChildA()));
> > > > suite.addTest(new
> MyTest("test3", new
> > ChildA()));
> > > > ........
> > > > suite.addTest(new
> MyTest("testN", new
> > ChildA()));
> > > >
> > > > // Then the same for childB
> > > > suite.addTest(new
> MyTest("test1", new
> > ChildB()));
> > > > suite.addTest(new
> MyTest("test2", new
> > ChildB()));
> > > > suite.addTest(new
> MyTest("test3", new
> > ChildB()));
> > > > ........
> > > > suite.addTest(new
> MyTest("testN", new
> > ChildB()));
> > > > return suite;
> > > > }
> > > > public static void main(String[] args)
> > > > {
> > > >
> > > junit.swingui.TestRunner.run(MyTestClient.class);
> > > > }
> > > > }
> > > >
> > > >How I would like to write the suite method is
> something like
> > this:
> > > >
> > > > public static Test suite()
> > > > {
> > > > TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> > > >
> > > > suite.addTest(MyTest.class /**
> Parameter here to
> > indicate
> > > I
> > > >want to test ChildA */)
> > > > suite.addTest(MyTest.class /**
> Parameter here to
> > indicate
> > > I
> > > >want to test ChildB */)
> > > > }
> > > >
> > > >Hope this is a sensible question!
> > > >
> > > >James
